title: A 45-year-old Tennis Coach with Lateral Elbow Tendinitis
clinical_history: John is a 45-year-old tennis coach at a local club. He has been coaching tennis for over 10 years and has recently increased his coaching load.  About 6 weeks ago, he started to notice a gradual onset of pain on the lateral aspect of his right elbow, which has progressively worsened. The pain is more pronounced when he is coaching and hitting backhands. He reports that he has not changed his technique but has been using a new racket with a slightly different grip size. He has also been playing more frequently, often coaching 6 days a week.

nprs.affected_area: lateral elbow pain, described as sharp and aching

aggrevating_factors: coaching tennis, especially backhand shots, gripping the racket, lifting heavy objects, and direct pressure on the lateral elbow
picture: A 24-hour picture showing a person holding a tennis racket with an emphasis on the lateral elbow
past_history: Had a similar episode of lateral elbow pain 5 years ago, which resolved with physical therapy and rest. He has a history of overuse injuries, including a stress fracture in his left foot 2 years ago.
medical_history: Generally healthy, but has high cholesterol and hypertension, which are well-managed with medication.
medications: Ibuprofen 400mg 3 times a day as needed for pain and inflammation
personal_history: Married with two children, both in high school. He is very active and enjoys playing tennis, hiking, and cycling in his free time.
imaging: X-rays of the elbow showed no signs of fractures or osteoarthritis, but ultrasound revealed inflammation and tendon thickening consistent with tendinitis.
